newsitem.title: IRAN: Iran moderate Khatami elected president.
newsitem.headline: Iran moderate Khatami elected president.

text.p: Iran's moderate former culture minister Mohammad Khatami was elected president on Saturday in a stunning upset victory over the Islamic republic's conservative establishment.
His main rival, conservative parliamentary speaker Ali Akbar Nateq-Nouri, conceded defeat after more than 17 million votes had been counted showing a Khatami landslide.
Tehran radio said he sent a letter of congratulations to Khatami and told him: "I will do my best to cooperate with you."
Khatami will take over in August from President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, who must step down after completing the maximum two four-year terms permitted by law.
The result was a major shock to the religious establishment which has ruled Iran since fundamentalist mullahs toppled the pro-American Shah in 1979.
On partial returns from the 17 million votes counted so far, Khatami won two out of every three votes cast in Friday's nationwide ballot, seen by many as a referendum on 18 years of revolution.
Nateq-Nouri had been widely predicted to take the presidency despite what many Iranian analysts and Western diplomats had forecast would be a close contest.

In the event he was relegated to second place with 28 percent of the vote while two lesser-known other candidates were far behind with relatively insignificant numbers of votes. Both Khatami and Nateq-Nouri are 54-year-old middle-ranking Shi'ite Moslem clergymen.

But Khatami is considered a moderate compared with most of the conservative clerics who run the country. Nateq-Nouri is a traditionalist who enjoys the support of influential groups of conservative mullahs and merchants.
Some 33 million people aged 15 and over were eligible to vote. Interior Ministry officials said turnout was high.

During the 12-day election campaign Khatami attracted a broad coalition of centrists close to Rafsanjani, Islamist left-wingers and women, youths and intellectuals seeking a more relaxed application of Islamic mores.

The coalition was formed to counter conservatives accused by Khatami's supporters of trying to monopolise state power by adding the presidency to their control of the 270-seat parliament, where Nateq-Nouri holds sway.
Khatami, an ayatollah's son, is considered an open-minded religious intellectual and tolerant politician.
He advocates more personal freedom, democracy and the rule of law in a country of 60 million where many complain state bodies act arbitrarily and rules are changed according to the whim of officials.
He also appeals to devout Shi'ites because he holds the title Seyyed and wears a black turban -- signs that he is believed to be descended from Islam's founder the Prophet Mohammad.
The result was a blow to Iran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who outranks the president and tacitly supported Nateq-Nouri.
He urged voters to choose the "best qualified" candidate, someone who could "stand against America and those who want to impose their will on our nation".
